prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum and spectral line mapping of 70 Hi-GAL clumps toward the l=224 field
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Two spectral windows are used to cover the CS(3-2) and CH3CN(8-7) lines, and three non-overlapping 2GHz basebands are used for continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to recover the cMF, and not the CMF (see Scientific Justification), we require high-angular (~2arcsec) resolution observations to detect and separate cores (but without resolving them further) down to a level of ~0.01pc (at a distance of 1kpc), allowing us to study the ultimate level of fragmentation prior to collapse of an individual core into a proto-star. ALMA is thus the right instrument for the proposed study, in terms of its angular resolution, sensitivity, its capability to recover "extended" structures, and the relatively large primary beam of the antennas.
Our simulations with the OST have shown that the best trade-off is achieved at a wavelength of ~2mm. At 3mm, with the same angular resolution, sensitivity decreases, while at 1mm ACA is required to recover emission from extended features, and primary beam attenuation is also a problem, given the clump sizes (~10"-20"). Since we are interested in mapping compact structures (<~0.1pc), the maximum recoverable structure of about 17arcsec with ALMA configuration C34-1 at 2mm is adequate and we do not require ACA. This will prevent us from underestimating the total flux (hence, the mass) of a given core, leading to a more reliable cMF.
In order to test different observational scenarios, we have preferred to use a simple model rather than a pre-existing image. In fact, the model allows to tune the parameters in a controlled manner, leading to a more meaningful comparison in terms of configurations, wavelengths and sensitivity. We have therefore built a simple model with three (spherical) dense cores (at a distance of 1kpc and with central temperatures varying from 15 to 25K) surrounded by a colder shell and envelope. Both temperature and column density decreases radially and the core radii vary from 0.01 to 0.02pc, yielding total core masses of ~1 to 3Msun. The expected column density distribution has been converted into flux density at the desired wavelengths and a background emission has been added.
The original model and the returned images by the OST are shown in Fig.2(a) of the Scientific Justification. Here we can note that the two warmer and more compact cores (at the bottom of the image) are clearly imaged by ALMA; however, the larger core (on top of the image), less compact and with a colder, more extended envelope is detected at 2mm, but it has been almost completely filtered out in the 1mm map. The peak intensity of the three individual cores vary from ~1 to 9mJy/beam in band 4, whereas it varies from ~1 to 6mJy/beam in band 6. A sensitivity of <~0.1mJy/beam is thus adequate to map even the weak features in the 2mm waveband image. In fact, our simulations show that with 3min integration time (assuming 5.6GHz bandwidth) we will be able to detect cores with a mass <~0.1 Msun (with T_dust~20K).
Although our main goal is to map the dust continuum, we will also have a spectral setup. In band 4 we will be able to observe simultaneously the CS(3-2) as well as the CH3CN(8-7) lines. Both molecules are tracers of high density gas and CH3CN is also a good thermometer, but difficult to observe in these cores. CS(3-2) is the most likely transition to be detected towards the Hi-GAL clumps. Our simulations using the cores model described above show that with 3min integration time, 0.2km/s spectral resolution, and a molecular abundance of X[CS]~10^(-9), the CS(3-2) line will be detectable in some cores (see Fig.2(b) of the Scientific Justification).
Assuming an integration time of ~3min, the total time request for 70 objects, estimated by the AOT, amounts to 7.3hr and will yield a sensitivity of about 0.08mJy/beam in band 4 (effective bandwidth of 5.6GHz) with an effective angular resolution of about 2.5arcsec. The spectral sensitivity (effective resolution 0.2 km/s) will be 18mJy/beam and will allow detection of the strongest CS(3-2) lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Stars form in dense, dusty clumps and the observed similarity between their mass distribution and the IMF supports the accepted idea that clumps fragment into sub-structures (cores) which then form stars. However, the transition from the observed "clump mass function" (CMF) to the IMF is still poorly understood theoretically, and not well constrained observationally. We propose to map with ALMA the structure of 70 Hi-GAL clumps, in order to study the ultimate level of fragmentation prior to collapse of an individual core into a proto-star. We want to compare the "core mass function" (cMF) with the IMF and also want to study its variations with mass range, clump position on/off the filaments and also as a function of starless and proto-stellar clumps. The proposed region is well defined and studied by the Hi-GAL team, it is relatively nearby and its distance has no near/far ambiguity, and offers the possibility to carry out the proposed analysis with a very good statistical significance. Our simulations show that band 4 offers the best trade-off in terms of minimum detectable mass and sensitivity to extended emission, without the need to use ACA.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
